Tera Van Beilen attended White Oaks Seco.page_content:
When Tera Van Beilen was 9 years old, she did what most 9-year-olds do when left to their own devices.

Nothing.

Oakville’s Van Beilen was a hyperactive, sporadically sporty kid, but her parents thought she could use some athletic direction.

“I was sort of going through a chubby phase,” Van Beilen says, chin tucked in to her chest and smiling shyly.

They took Tera to a local club for swimming lessons, half-hoping she’d like it. She was the family’s most enthusiastic user of the backyard pool (she remembers summer days with her sister, Marya, dropping marbles into the deep end, seeing who could come up with the most).

This wasn’t a Eureka moment. Tera liked swimming enough to make it a regular thing. She got pretty good at it pretty fast. The coaches on hand pressed the Van Beilens to intensify Tera’s twice-a-week training schedule.

But through grade school it remained a hobby and a physical outlet, rather than an obsession.

Today, Van Beilen, a distinctly unchubby 18-year-old, is headed to the London Olympics, a surprise medal contender in the 100m and 200m breaststroke.

Genetics must have something to do with this. Her uncle, Wayne Van Dorp, played for the Blackhawks and the Penguins. Her cousin, Joel Reinders, is an offensive tackle with the New York Giants.

“He’s the one protecting Eli Manning. Or is it Peyton Manning? I’m not sure. One of the Mannings,” Van Beilen said.

The illusion of athletic effortlessness is also a family thing. Reinders played only eight games of football at any level before being signed by the Cleveland Browns.

Like her gargantuan cousin, Van Beilen’s progression is proof to parents everywhere that a child can master a sport without sacrificing every other thing it means to be a child.

“They let me have swimming and still have school. I had both worlds,” Van Beilen says.

Right into high school, Van Beilen played other sports. It wasn’t until age 15 that she made swimming her focus.

A great many athletic stories — both amateur and pro — start precociously early and are filled with nothing from then on but practice and competition. In an extreme example, 10-year-old Alexander Ovechkin played in a hockey tournament the day after his brother died.

Van Beilen went to a regular school — Oakville’s Kings Christian Collegiate — rather than a sporting academy. On Friday nights, she watched Say Yes to the Dress with her mom. She went out with friends on Saturdays. She attended the birthright of all typical teens — the prom.

Even after swimming became her job, she treated it like one — a Monday-to-Friday thing. However, it was an exhausting Monday to Friday thing.

She was cut a few breaks at school. Teachers would occasionally let her go out to her car and sleep through a class. Her mother, Sharon, an administrator at the school, set up a quiet room for Van Beilen to nap through her spares.

She graduated last year. She now attends Swimming Canada’s branch office in Vancouver, the University of British Columbia. Five of Canada’s pool Olympians were studying and training at UBC last year.

A year ago, the Olympics were a dream for Van Beilen. Literally. She began having dreams about touching the wall, looking up at the clock and seeing herself qualified. She has a picture of the rings pasted over her bed at home and at school.

But that’s all they were. At that point Van Beilen was ranked 18th in the world in the 100-metre event, and 23rd in the 200-metre. That put her 5th and 3rd, respectively, on Canada’s depth chart in events where only two competitors qualify.

In February, hope began to turn to belief when she finished first in the 100-metre at the CIS Championships and a narrow second to UBC teammate and fellow Olympian Martha McCabe in the 200.

“That was when I began to say to myself, ‘I know I can do this’.”

In March, she went to the Olympic trials in Montreal. She first qualified in the 100-metre by placing second, a mild surprise. But it was her performance in the 200-metre that brought her to global attention.

Van Beilen finished first in the 200-metre final, pushing third-place finisher and current world record holder Annamay Pierse off Canada’s Olympic team. Her time of 2:24:03 was, at that point, the second fastest in the world this year.

The day after qualifying, she flew back to Vancouver to sit a physiology exam she had very purposely put out of her mind while she concentrated on the trials. She got a 57.

“Mom, I got a 57!” Van Beilen excitedly told her mother. Sharon was less excited.

She looks pretty excited now, snapping pictures of Star photographer Steve Russell while he takes pictures of Tera sitting on the diving board of that family pool. Sharon’s wearing a Team Van Beilen t-shirt. Tera’s childhood trophies are piled up in boxes in the hallway of their Oakville cottage. They’ve just returned from display at Tera’s grade school.

Father Harry, an executive with Tim Hortons, drifts in on his lunch hour to take in the scene. The Van Beilens didn’t push their daughter into sport, but they’re enjoying watching her flower in that world.

“I think Tera likes it, too,” Harry says, in that teasing way a father says things within earshot of his children.

“Likes what?” Tera says.

“The attention,” Harry says.

“Right, dad,” Tera drawls sarcastically, 18 going on 13 for just a moment. They catch each other’s eye and smile. This has the feel of a family routine that’s been perfected over many years.

Nobody made Tera Van Beilen do anything. Left to her own youthful devices, she has put herself on the cusp of something that will last long after youth has faded.

RELATED

Profile: Diver Jennifer Abel

Profile: Swimmer Julia Wilkinson

Profile: Mountain biker Catharine Pendrel

Profile: Rowing’s Lesley Thompson-Willie

London Olympic quiz

KEY COMPETITORS

Rebecca Soni, U.S.A.100 and 200 No woman in the world dominates a single stroke the way Soni dominates breaststroke. She has three Olympic medals, has held four world records and is the defending world champion at both the 100m and 200m distance. Soni is the clear favourite in both of Van Beilen’s events.

Jessica Hardy, U.S.A.100 The world’s dominant breaststroker until a doping suspension cost her an appearance in Beijing, where Soni eclipsed her. She’s the defending U.S. champion at this distance and the current world record holder.

“Other than those two, it’s pretty close afterward. It’s anyone’s game,” says Van Beilen. “Whoever can deal with the pressure at that moment can succeed. And that’s one thing I think I’m pretty good at.”

SHARE:

Biography

Tera Van Beilen admits she used to have excessive dreams about making the Olympic team. Those dreams became reality in 2012 when she got as close as she could get to advancing to the 100m breaststroke final in London, losing a swim-off for the eighth spot in the final to Jamaica’s Alia Atkinson. Van Beilen also competed in the 200m breaststroke after winning the event at the Canadian Trials, knocking world record holder Annamay Pierse off the Canadian Olympic team in the process. Van Beilen had competed at the inaugural Youth Olympic Games in 2010, winning three medals including gold in the 100m breaststroke. Her multi-sport competition experience includes the 2011 and 2013 Universiades, where she won a pair of silver medals in her first appearance. Van Beilen made her FINA World Championship debut in 2013. She has been part of four straight CIS championship teams with the UBC Thunderbirds.

GETTING TO KNOW…

Family: Parents Harry and Sharon Van Beilen… Older brother Nathan… Younger sister Marya… Uncle Wayne Van Dorp is a former NHL player… Cousin Joel Reinders is a CFL offensive lineman… Getting into the Sport: Learned to swim at age 5 in the backyard pool because she was a chubby child… Started swimming competitively at age 9… Was disqualified from her first meet for moving her toes… Outside Interests: Kinesiology major at the University of British Columbia… Enjoys baking and cooking… Played piano for 10 years… Odds and Ends: Nicknames: Teddy, TVB… Athlete ambassador for KidSport… Collects magnets during her travels… Favourite motto: Do my best, let God do the rest… Likes to eat yogurt-covered raisings before competing… Has a maple leaf tattoo on her toe, making it the last thing she sees before diving off the blocks…

INTERNATIONAL RESULTS

FINA World Championships: 2013 – 28th (100m breaststroke), 21st (200m breaststroke)

Youth Olympic Games: 2010 – GOLD (100m breaststroke), SILVER (200m breaststroke), BRONZE (4x100m freestyle relay), 4th (4x100m medley relay)

Pan Pacific Championships: 2014 – 12th (100m breaststroke), 12th (200m breaststroke)

Commonwealth Games: 2014 – 6th (100m breaststroke), 9th (200m breaststroke), BRONZE (4x100m medley relay)

A trio of Grade 12 students from White Oaks Secondary School (WOSS) have achieved rare perfect scores in their International Baccalaureate (IB) programme. Olivia Lau, Heather Li and Harrison Thorpe all scored 45 out of 45 in all subject areas.

According to a press release from Halton District School Board, "the IB program is a world-recognized, two-year diploma, which provides a challenging curriculum for highly motivated students."

Heather Li gave credit to her teachers: “I’m very thankful to the teachers at WOSS who I think are a large part in why we had so many perfect scores this year and in the past few years as well. I’m grateful that the work we’ve put in over the past two years has culminated in the scores we received, especially since almost a year and a half of our IB experience was during a pandemic.” Li will be studying liberal arts at the University of Oxford in England this fall.

Harrison Thorpe says, “I’m really excited to move to a new place and experience a different environment. Although my area of study is commerce, I hope to foster my passion for music by participating in the university’s wind orchestra.” Thorpe will be attending McGill University to study economics and finance.

Olivia Lau, who was elected HDSB student trustees for the 2019-20 says lots of hard work went into her results. “When I reflect upon the past two years in this rigorous program, I can’t help but think of the countless late nights and all of the hard work that led up to this result.” Lau will be attending McMaster University to study health sciences.

Remarkably, this was not the first IB "hat trick" for White Oaks Secondary School. In 2018 Brian Guo, Hanson Liu and Dasha Metropolitansky also had the distinction of scoring perfect scores.

Erin Davidson, IB Programme Coordinator for WOSS says that “along with the additional individual academic work, IB students are encouraged to get involved in their community and school, and to be physically active. Olivia, Heather and Harrison embody the spirit of the IB programme. (These) students give back to the community while attaining personal growth goals, such as taking risks and being a respectful global citizen.”

In Oakville, the IB Program is offered at White Oaks by Halton Public School Board and St. Thomas Aquinas Catholic Secondary School by Halton Catholic School Board.

The average test scores for IB students worldwide was 33.02 out of 45 this year.

奥克维尔(Oakville)又称橡树村，是一个富裕的湖畔小镇，地处安大略湖西岸，属于荷顿区(Halton Region), 南面濒临安大略湖，西邻伯灵顿，北接米尔顿，东面则与皮尔区密西沙加为邻，是大多伦多地区的一部分。根据最新政府网站信息，奥克维尔有约22.5万居民，城市总面积为138.5平方公里。奥克维尔市是加拿大第二富裕城市。

加拿大经济类杂志Moneysense杂志每年将加拿大415个地区的经济状况，治安，气候，交通，税收，房价可负担性，及基础设施状况进行统计。通过相应算法将数据进行加权并排名，给出加拿大最宜居地区排行榜。2018年，Oakville最终荣登榜首，这已经是我们奥村连续5年获此殊荣了。

作为移民多年的本地居民，Michael我为大家从多方面来梳理一下这个堪称“多伦多后花园”的珍宝小镇。

交通

奥克维尔镇内有三条衔接400系列公路的高速公路，分别为伊丽莎白皇后大道（QEW）、403号公路和407号收费公路。QEW在奥克维尔镇内的大部分路段与403号公路连接，开车到多伦多市中心约35分钟，到尼亚加拉大瀑布及美国边境约60分钟，瀑布对岸就是美国的水牛城，到多伦多皮尔逊国际机场约30分钟，到传统华人区万锦、列治文山约50分钟。一到节假日或长周末，奥克维尔很多人会开车去大瀑布及周边游玩，顺便到那里的免税店购物， 或者来个美国几日游。

奥克维尔内的公共交通大巴(Oakville Transit) 覆盖每一条主要街道，无缝衔接Go Train站。从东部Oakville和西部Bronte两个车站可往返于多伦多市中心和奥克维尔，车站配有停车场满足通勤的上班族需求。去多伦多市中心的Union（联合总站）仅需20分钟，而且车次频繁，从清晨5点多直至深夜，早上和下午高峰期还有至Union的直达快车。我有很多朋友就是在多伦多的市中心上班，每天早晚通过Go Train 通勤，既省心准时，也免去了自己开车的疲惫，上班时间和精力有保证。另外中长途轻轨的 Via Rail 服务在Oakville 站有停靠站。





城市公交车(Transit Bus)

跨城市轨道公交(Go Train)

城市环境

虽然奥克维尔是个City, 奥克维尔居民都引以自豪地自称为“镇”，华人称奥村，西人自称”proud of being a town”，市政府叫Town of Oakville。Michael认为，奥克维尔的定位是个宜居的小镇，生活养娃的福地，没有大城市那种繁华喧嚣的高层写字楼和商业中心，没有高密度人群的高楼公寓。我们住在视野开阔的别墅区，享受高素质的邻里社区和学校教育。奥克维尔的安大略湖海滨拥有两座美丽的天然良港，到了夏季，会泊满随时出游的船只，港口更提供给居民许多划船及其他水上运动的场地。市内遍布公园、Trail、草地，图书馆。这里气候宜人，环境美丽，森林覆盖率达到27.8%，比著名的花园城市温哥华还高2%。最出名的景点有Sixteen Mile(十六里溪)、Bronte Creek Provincial Park、Lakeside Park、Oakville镇中心等等。





(湖滨公园及港口)





(十六里溪边的Glen Abbey高尔夫球场)

(奥克维尔镇中心)





城市经济

奥克维尔是众多知名企业的总部所在地，包括福特汽车加拿大分公司(林肯MKX总装厂)、建筑公司Mattamy Homes的总部、加拿大古德里奇航空总部、加拿大GE水处理总部及加拿大快餐连锁店Tim Hortons总部。小城经济发达，有汽车、电器、炼油等工业，这里文化教育产业发达，交通便利，是加拿大最富裕的城市之一。2021年居民平均家庭年收入更高达19.8万加币，远远高于安省平均的11万加币，65%以上的家庭年收入超过10万加币。

福特组装厂

本地居民的职业都非常好，很多从事IT、律师、医疗，管理，金融，财务等高薪酬工作，还有不少有自己的business或自雇的人士，56%的居民是大学本科以上学历。这也是为什么奥克维尔人均收入较高的原因之一。奥克维尔还在继续吸引着这些中产精英搬到这里来居住，尤其东湖区更是富豪云集。家在奥村，工作在多伦多或密西沙加成为一种常态。

*数据来源: https://invest.oakville.ca/data.html

Profile table, Census Profile, 2021 Census of Population





社区

Oakville纵向从东到西主要以八线、Trafalgar、六线、十六里溪、三线、Bronte Rd等为界，横向从南到北主要以QEW，Upper Middle Rd，Dundas Rd为界划分社区。社区的历史从大湖边向北辐射发展。沿着湖边向北发展的时间顺序：依次为红、橙、紫、绿。

下图是多伦多地产局(TREB)划分的奥克维尔社区：

沿着湖边向北发展的时间顺序：依次为红、橙、紫、绿

下图是奥克维尔/米尔顿地产局(OMDREB)划分的奥克维尔社区：





奥村各区各有特色，从上百年的老房子，到最新建的房子和翻新屋，能看到建筑风格随着时代的变迁在演变。东湖区(Eastlake)历史悠久，房子地块很大，房子被参天大树包围，仿佛住在童话森林中，东湖区是“多伦多十大富豪区”之一；Glen Abbey房子地块较大，绿化不错，有年代感;Joshua Creek、West Oak Trails和Rural Oakville房龄较新，街道整齐，但密度偏大。

奥克维尔还有一个特点，就是Trail特别多，天然氧吧，适合晨跑、饭后散步、遛弯遛狗，偶尔还会遇上coyote(郊狼)。

小区的步道Trail

“狼出没”提示

所有社区都按人口比例配套学校、公园、运动设施、诊所、商圈和服务机构。

我以后单独写介绍各社区的文章，在此不一一赘述了。

Michael给大家分享一个GTA所有社区的链接（在右上角勾选”Communities”）：

http://www.torontomls.net/Communities/map.html

社区活动

奥克维尔有许多各类俱乐部和活动群，童子军(Scouts/Cadets)、各种球类、绘画、音乐、摄影、美食、团购、教育、Hiking、华人协会、老年活动俱乐部，兴趣相投的居民相继组织活动群，让我们华人在加拿大的生活不再是“好山好水好寂寞”。

奥克维尔庆祝加拿大国庆节

奥克维尔市政府迎中国新年

奥克维尔老年合唱团

奥克维尔2023年春晚

奥克维尔华人足球俱乐部

族裔分布

根据奥克维尔政府网站最新显示，截止2022年奥克维尔人口为225,000，居民族裔背景分布如下：





Oakville 的人口构成以欧洲裔为主，尤其英裔，所以欧洲文化对当地的人文环境产生很大影响，奥克维尔曾有“英国村”的称号。由于奥村生活环境好，受到越来越多高净值的中产新移民追捧，华裔比例逐年增加。

学校教育

奥克维尔最吸引人的地方，除了生活环境，就是它的教育资源。奥村拥有加拿大最好的公校私校以及素质教育资源，小学/高中在安省排名靠前的双学区很普遍，所以在这里没有“差学区”，都是“好学区”或是“更好学区”，实际差别并不大。

公立学校

在加拿大著名智库Fraser Institute（菲莎研究所）排行榜中，奥克维尔的学校平均排名多年保持在安省前列。

以下是2019年奥克维尔高中的菲莎排名

以下是2019年奥克维尔小学(K8)的菲莎排名及对应高中

PILGRIM WOOD小学边界

JOSHUA CREEK小学边界

*备注：找小学高中排名都好的双学区的社区，请按以上对应表，以及学区边界，只有在学区边界内的有租房或自住房的居民才能报名对应的学校，篇幅有限不能一一列出，具体详情咨询Michael.





奥克维尔镇内的公立中小学以主要授课语言和宗教背景分为四个类别，并由数间不同机构营运：

荷顿区教育局(Halton District School Board)：负责营运镇内的英语公立中小学

Abbey Park High School Iroquois Ridge High School Oakville Trafalgar High School T. A. Blakelock High School White Oaks Secondary School Garth Webb Secondary School





荷顿区天主教教育局(Halton Catholic District School Board)：负责营运镇内的英语天主教公立中小学

维亚蒙德教育局(Conseil scolaire Viamonde)：负责营运镇内的法语公立中小学

中南部天主教教育局(Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud)：负责营运镇内的法语天主教公立中小学。

IB课程：公立白橡树高中(White Oaks Secondary School) 和圣托马斯天主教高中 (St. Thomas Aquinas Catholic Secondary School )提供深受欢迎的IB课程 (the International Baccalaureate Program)。





著名私校

奥克维尔的私校资源也非常丰富：

一百多年历史的顶级男女混校私立学校 Appleby College

女子私校 St. Mildred's-Lightbourn School (SMLS)

男子私校 Linbrook School

Chisholm Academy





大学

谢尔丹学院（Sheridan College）的主校区也坐落于Oakville。大名鼎鼎的谢尔丹一直以来都被誉为世界上最好的动画院校之一，该校的动画相关专业全球闻名，堪称“动画界的哈佛”，为好莱坞输送了大批人才。并且谢尔丹学院毕业生曾经多次获得过奥斯卡奖，艾美奖中动画相关奖项。来自重庆的加拿大华裔女导演Domee Shi（石之予）作品《包宝宝》获奖第91届奥斯卡金像奖最佳动画短片！她就是该学校动画专业本科毕业的！她的新作品《哪吒》也准备参选角逐第92届奥斯卡奖项。

2020年4月，在美国动画职业评论(Animation Career Review) 对185所世界知名艺术高校的专业排名中，谢尔丹动画再次蝉联世界第一。





在奥村，应运而生了一些动漫绘画兴趣班，专业指导报考谢尔丹学院。

购物餐饮

在奥克维尔每3公里半径内总有一个社区商圈能基本满足生活所需，里面进驻了各类连锁超市、快餐店、咖啡厅、银行、邮政等生活配套。随着华人数量的增加，越来越多的华人商家店铺把服务和门店拓展到奥克维尔，2020年底在Oakville Go Train站旁边迎来了奥村首家华人超市Famijoy(润万家)。 奥村及旁边的密市有各地餐饮包括：港式餐厅、粤菜、川菜、湘菜、上海菜、凉皮、拉面、新疆菜、日本料理以及家庭厨房等等。

(奥克维尔的商圈)





20分钟左右车程可到达邻近的密西沙加市的Square One大型商业中心、Costco、黄金广场、华人超市、中国城，以及品牌店多伦多奥特莱斯Toronto Premium Outlets。

‍(奥克维尔邻近城市大商圈)





医疗

加拿大的医疗体系是预约制，全民都有家庭医生，有问题先找家庭医生预约看病，家庭医生解决不了就会安排转诊到大医院或其它专科机构。新搬入的居民需要在社区联络一位家庭医生入档挂靠，大病小病都会跟踪。身体不舒服想看医生，需要提前与家庭医生预约候诊。如果想看急诊，可以直接去社区walk-in clinic或大医院急诊科(Emergency)排队挂号，不必预约。奥村的华人家庭医生目前屈指可数，现在已不接收新病人，也有个别西人医生每周定期安排中文翻译接诊华人。邻近的Mississauga有不少华人医生、牙医和中医，还有北京同仁堂药店可以买到中草药以及问诊。

新移民找家庭医生链接：

https://www.halton.ca/For-Residents/Public-Health/Halton-Physicians-Accepting-New-Patients

位于三线/Dundas的Oakville Trafalgar Memorial Hospital





政治政府

由于奥克维尔的宜居教育环境吸引了各国中产精英，越来越多的华人家庭移居到这里。如今，华裔已经成为 Oakville 的第二大少数族裔。作为一直扎根社区热忱服务的优秀华人代表，谢爱军博士 (Dr.Scott Xie ) 成为Oakville建城165年以来首位华裔市议员！创造了华裔参政新历史，为华人发声，为亚裔发声！2023年5月，Oakville市迎来第一个“亚洲传统文化月” 活动由市里的华人议员Scott提出，获得全体议员通过。5月1日上午10am，将在Oakville Town Hall（1225 Trafalga Rd）举行“亚洲传统文化月启动暨升旗仪式”

谢爱军博士 (Dr.Scott Xie ) 成为Oakville建城165年以来首位华裔市议员

2023年5月，Oakville市迎来第一个“亚洲传统文化月”

治安

加拿大杂志Maclean’s 根据237个市镇的犯罪率数据，给出了一份比较全面的治安排名统计Canada’s Most Dangerous Places 2020，数据从治安最差到治安最好的市镇排列（治安越好，CSI指数越小，排名越靠后）。Oakville 所在Halton地区犯罪率排在全国215名，安省最低，说明治安非常好。

*数据来自https://www.macleans.ca/canadas-most-dangerous-places-2020/





气候

Oakville四季分明，夏季不是太热，超过30°C的天数不多；冬天也不太冷，下暴雪的次数不多。由于邻安大略湖，受大湖效应影响，奥克维尔的冬天比大多地区北部如Richmond Hill 和Markham暖和1-2°C，而夏天却要凉快一些。

全年平均气温





房地产市场

奥克维尔的住宅以低层房屋为主，住宅市场主要可以分为三大类：独立屋 (独栋别墅/Detached House)，镇屋 (联排屋/Townhouse, Stack house) 和高层公寓 (Apartment)。其中独立屋占58.6%，半独立屋和联排占21.4%，公寓占20%。

从近几年GTA房产市场的整体表现来看，奥克维尔是西部房产市场一颗宝石，这里房价比较健康，没有大起大落，而是平稳上涨。在2017年市场最疯狂的时候没有偏离市场价值太多，经过两年的回调盘整，现在已经超过当时的高点。简而言之，奥克维尔的房子是保值的潜力股！

房子均价最贵的要数大湖边上的东湖区 (Eastlake) ，它是奥村历史最久的社区，房子地块很大，以平房(Bungalow) 为主，近几年许多投资客及开发商陆续买下这些大地块房子，推倒翻建成大豪宅。多数房子在180~1000万加币区间。性价比最高好区在Glen Abbey, Iroquois Ridge North, West Oak Trails, College Park等，独立屋在150-200万左右，学校和基础设施比较成熟。由于新增移民的数量逐年增加，Rural Oakville是政府大力发展的新区，房龄在5年以内，价格也相对较高，还有许多在建项目和楼花期房，房型包括独立屋、镇屋、公寓，居住密度相对较大，配套的高中、公园和商圈有些滞后。

Joshua Creek 社区15年左右，独立屋房价在180~400万区间

Glen Abbey 社区30年左右，独立屋房价在150~380万区间

West Oak Trails社区20年左右，独立屋房价在130~180万区间

College Park 社区40年左右，独立屋房价在120~220万区间

2020年Covid-19疫情爆发以来，在加拿大每年吸收30-40万新移民、宽松的货币政策、住宅土地审批过慢，合力导致供需关系严重不平衡，整个GTA尤其Oakville的房产价格大幅上涨，截止目前涨幅达到30-50%之多。过度的货币宽松，导致2年的疯狂上涨，为了抑制通货膨胀，2022年4月13日加拿大央行开始加息，至2023年1月25日，连续加息7次，房价一路下跌，2023年有望企稳。(请见下图2022年全年奥克维尔独立屋和镇屋价格走势)

2022年，整个Oakville地区独立屋(Detached)房屋平均销售价格为$2,117,598，中位值为$1,835,000。

2022年，整个Oakville地区镇屋(Townhouse)房屋平均销售价格为$1,276,976，中位值为$1,240,000。

*数据来自多伦多地产局(TREB)2022年市场报告及http://51.ca

Profile table, Census Profile, 2021 Census of Population

以上数据仅做参考，Michael会在介绍各社区的文章里详细讨论房市的问题，在这就不展开说了。需要了解更多房产交易数据的朋友，可以与我联系。(微信 michaelatcanada)

地图找房

下面这个链接是“地图找房”，可以方便快捷地找到目标区域市场上挂牌出售和出租的房源：

https://michaelincanada.ca/map-search/

地图找房截图





这座加拿大史上最贵豪宅位于安省奥克维尔湖景东路 (Lakeshore Blvd) 1150号，占地4.7万加平方呎，居住面积为2.8万平方呎(居住面积略小于美国白宫)，后院直通安大略湖，有泊船位。挂牌价6500万加币。

综述

综上可以看出，Oakville在教育，气候，经济，治安等各方面都有不俗表现。奥克维尔既位于大多伦多都市圈，在享受大都市经济繁荣的同时，又有自己平静安逸的社区空间，是一个闹中取静的地方。华人越来越多的参与到奥克维尔的生活服务中，从政府、银行、商场、家庭医生、学校、社区服务等，还有提供各种服务和分享的微信群，这里的生活越来越便利。

孟母择邻而居，欢迎来到加拿大最宜居城市Oakville安家置业、留学读书。

作者本人

笔者Michael Zhang(张泉)移居Oakville多年，熟悉这里的一花一草，热爱这里的春夏秋冬，积极参与社区活动。作为奥克维尔本地资深地产经纪，多次获得公司铂金/金牌经纪大奖，长年从事房屋买卖，帮助移民朋友安家投资置业，以良好的人品赢得口碑和信任。

我是奥克维尔地产经纪人Broker，隶属北美知名地产公司Re/Max Realtron顶尖大奖团队Jim Mo Team，每年成交上百套房产，Re/Max加拿大及全球排名前50名，Re/Max Pinnacle Club Team Award 2021-2022"顶尖"团队荣誉大奖，个人多年获得公司白金金牌业绩大奖，Re/Max Platinum Club(白金) & 100% Club Award 。熟悉学区房、投资房、楼花，拥有Ultimate Academy® Home Staging证书，为卖家提供Staging、专业拍摄等售前美化包装服务。擅长谈判沟通，精通国语、粤语、英语。以客户的利益至上！是您值得托付的卖房和安居置业帮手。自身有丰富的多伦多楼花和二手房投资经验，专注大多伦多热点地区(奥克维尔、密市、万锦、烈治文山等)二手房及多伦多市中心公寓楼花买卖及租赁服务。我们服务社区，回馈社会，团队部分佣金通过Children's Miracle Network捐给儿童医院！我们2021-2022年连续每年捐款超过8000加元，是为数不多的SickKids Foundation认可的"Re/Max Miracle Office"之一！欢迎关注我的频道，及时获得各社区的介绍及资讯。

On Monday March 29, 2021, the Halton Regional Police Service received a report regarding racial slurs that had been spray painted on the grounds of White Oaks Secondary School in Oakville, Ontario. White Oaks is located at 1055 McCraney Street East.

According to the information received from a school staff member, inappropriate images and anti-Black racist language was spray painted on the turf, on the track, and on the bleachers. Officers attended the scene, and this incident remains under investigation at this time.

Police are appealing to anyone that may have witnessed this incident or has any relevant information to contact the 2 District Criminal Investigations Bureau at 905-825-4777 ext. 2216.

Tips can also be submitted anonymously to Crime Stoppers. "See something? Hear something? Know something? Contact Crime Stoppers" at 1-800-222-8477 (TIPS) or through the web at www.haltoncrimestoppers.ca.

Hate has no place in our communities. We encourage residents to report any incident that is motivated by hate or bias. We appreciate your cooperation in helping to eliminate these types of incidents from our communities.

April 12, 2022

Tera Van Beilen

Over the next few weeks, Swim Ontario is presenting the Canada Games Legacy Series, where we take a look back at swimmers who represented Team Ontario at past Canada Summer Games.

There is something to be said about inspiring girls to become confident in sport, and believe that greatness is possible.

Tera (Van Beilen) Maloney knows that feeling because she has experienced it. Now, in many ways, she’s an icon of success for others.

It may have been back when she was five years old, benefitting from a pool in her home backyard, that a light started to trickle. One of a youngster’s desire to be competitive, noticed, and having that desire to win.

Van Beilen, now married and whose maiden name we will use in this feature, has many stories about her younger years in the world of arts and sports. There were those ballet lessons, playing piano and the introduction to soccer.

But it was always swimming that superseded everything else.

She eloquently described it as “that urge to stay in the pool, never get out and even, at times, want to eat dinner while in the water”.

That may have been an early taste of what would lie ahead for this water baby.

There’s a New York city pop band, called American Authors, known for the song “The Best Days of My Life”. Listen to it. Tap your foot to the music, even sing along if you know the lyrics when you read more about Van Beilen.

“I had a dream so big and loud

I jumped so high I touched the clouds

Wo-o-o-o-o-oh, wo-o-o-o-o-oh

I stretched my hands out to the sky.”

Best Days of My Life, American Authors

It might be a tune that she may consider attaching to her prosperous swim career.

When mentioning the real inauguration to competitive swimming, this might surprise many. It wasn’t any of the events she competed in - the Commonwealth Games, FINA World championships or even the Summer Olympics.

It all started in 2009, in Charlottetown, P.E.I., at the Canada Summer Games.

Canada’s national spotlight on amateur sport was where Van Beilen would begin to relish fame with a remarkable performance and go on to win six gold medals.

“I remember it very well and asking myself – how did I do this,” she said in a recent telephone conversation. “Also, medalling at the Canadian Nationals and realizing that I was able to do more than just the breaststroke, but also compete in the relays and help my team. That was the year that started my competitive swim career.”

With the beautiful Niagara Region of Ontario hosting the 2022 Canada Summer Games in August, an event that brings together some 5,000 promising athletes, a mere mention of those days brings back fond memories for Van Beilen, who has a Maple Leaf tattoo on one of her toes.

“The Canada Summer Games were an incredible experience, a special time in my life and a glimpse at top level athletes in many sports,” she said, while also confirming a rumour that she liked to eat yoghurt-covered raisins before competing.

“Things were different in my day, as you could be a National calibre athlete in those Games. But now, it’s really focussed for younger kids with potential – more of a stepping stone for success, to experience and cherish the moment. It could very well be the start of something big for many.”

While she graduated from King’s Christian Collegiate in Oakville, a school that now has the “Van Beilen Endeavour Award” given to a student who excels in arts, music, or sports outside of school, her swim keys to success started with the Oakville Aquatic Club.

Choosing post-secondary education in Canada, over numerous athletic scholarship offers from schools throughout the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA), Van Beilen picked the University of British Columbia.

Not only did she continue her academic honors success, and left UBC with a Degree in Kinesiology, but she was on the Thunderbirds incredible swim team that won four consecutive Canadian Interuniversity Sports (now re-branded to USports) championships.

There was also the Swim Youth Olympics in Singapore, where she won three medals, that would come a year after the Canada Summer Games. One who excelled in the breaststroke, Van Beilen would add one major event after another. Then came the electrifying and emotional time in her life that she will never forget.

“The Canadian Olympic Trials in Montreal, I knew when I had touched the wall that made the qualifying time needed to make Canada’s team for the 2012 Games in London (England),” she said. “You can’t imagine the feeling of representing your country at the Olympics.”

That was the same Van Beilen, who didn’t like wearing swim goggles or a bathing cap as a youngster, and preferred to sleep in on mornings devoted to swim practices. That is, until her parents asked her to make a choice between sticking with swimming and its challenges, or packing it in. Judgment time, and she picked swimming and has never looked back.

Both her parents had been athletes, an uncle played in the National Hockey League and a cousin in the Canadian and National Football Leagues, the genes were in the family.

With her competitive days eventually now having come to a close, she really hasn’t bid adieu to the sport. She’s now Marketing Manager for Speedo Canada, a company that inspires swimmers by offering up a brand of stylish merchandise.

“Swimming helped me in life and brought me so much joy,” she said. “There were many times when I could laugh, cry through my goggles, release so much energy, and allow me to make friends for life.”



David Grossman is a veteran multi award-winning Journalist and Broadcaster with some of Canada’s major media, including the Toronto Star and SPORTSNET 590 THE FAN, and a Public Relations professional for 45+ years in Canadian sports and Government relations.

Three GTA students have achieved rare perfect scores in their International Baccalaureate (IB) program, and in an equally rare twist, all are graduates of the same Oakville high school.

Brian Guo, Hanson Liu and Dasha Metropolitansky all attended White Oaks Secondary School.

The two-year IB diploma program demands "academic rigour in languages, mathematics, humanities and sciences and emphasizes personal development for students," according to a press release issued by the Halton District School Board.

"When I saw the number on the screen, I refreshed a couple of times just because I didn't believe it," said Metropolitansky.

"I definitely yelled out loud. It was honestly a surreal moment because IB is so hard," she said

"And from my school, I think there has been only one other student in 10 years of running the IB program, who has received a perfect score. So then, for myself to receive a perfect score, and two others in my year, it was a bit surreal."

Dasha Metropolitansky, who was the youngest person to ever to represent Canada on the national debate team, leaves for Harvard next week to begin her university studies. (submitted by Dasha Metropolitansky)

"I owe my peers, teachers and White Oaks administration so much for providing me with excellent resources and counsel" said Guo.

"Aside from feeling extremely grateful, I am very proud that the three of us can represent White Oaks," Liu said. "I hope this showcases the quality of the HDSB staff and resources that paved the road to our achievement."

Metropolitansky, 18, became a super achiever early in life. She was the youngest person ever to represent Canada on the national debate team, and has travelled to international competitions in the U.S, the United Kingdom, Singapore, Turkey, Germany and the Czech Republic.

In Bali, Indonesia last year, Metropolitansky was ranked the second best individual debater in the world. She opted out of competing this year due to the demands of the IB program.

Watch Dasha Metropolitansky debate the appeal of Donald Trump to voters ahead of the 2016 U.S. election on CBC's The National:

"I think it's a bit crazy that only 13 students received a perfect score in North and South America in 2018, and pretty much a quarter of those came from one school, particularly a public school ... which I think is so impressive I don't think there is any private school around here that can say they have that same result," she said.

Metropolitansky gives school staff credit for the achievement..

"The teachers do a really good job. Every single year they look at our results,how can we improve," she said.

"They go through the detailed feedback that they get from the International Baccalaureate program, and they try to incorporate that in their teaching, so I think it really is a testament to the IB staff at White Oaks and the group of students we had [this year].

"I know many teachers met with other IB teachers and staff from IB so that they can learn more updated information about how IB marking works, and how they can improve their teaching."

Metropolitansky leaves for Harvard next week to begin her university studies. She also applied to Stanford, Princeton and Cambridge Law and was accepted at all four universities.

This fall, Guo is pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Economics from Duke University and Liu is studying Health Sciences at McMaster University.

× Expand HDSB International Baccalaureate

The Halton District School Board is pleased to announce that three students from White Oaks Secondary School in Oakville – Brian Guo, Hanson Liu and Dasha Metropolitansky – have achieved rare perfect scores in their International Baccalaureate programme.

The International Baccalaureate programme is an internationally recognized, two-year diploma, which provides a challenging curriculum for highly motivated students. It offers additional academic rigor in languages, mathematics, humanities and sciences and emphasizes personal development for students. It is offered at 5,000 schools around the world, including three in the Halton District School Board: Georgetown District High School, Robert Bateman High School and White Oaks Secondary School.

According to the International Baccalaureate organization, only 13 students in the ‘Americas’ region achieved a perfect score (45 points), and three are students from the same school in the Halton District School Board.

“I owe my peers, teachers and White Oaks administration so much for providing me with excellent resources and counsel, without which my accomplishment would not have been possible,” Guo says. “I am honoured to have received a 45, but I am most appreciative of the IB for its formative impact on me as a learner and as a global citizen.”

“Aside from feeling extremely grateful, I am very proud that the three of us can represent White Oaks,” Lui says. “I hope this showcases the quality of the HDSB staff and resources that paved the road to our achievement, and encourages more students to pursue this wonderful educational opportunity.”

“I’m extremely proud that I’m one of only 13 students in North and South America who achieved a perfect score in such a demanding program,” Metropolitansky says. “The fact that approximately a quarter of North and South America’s perfect scores came from the Halton District School Board is extraordinary and a testament to the quality of our schools.”

"The Halton District School Board is very proud of the scores Brian, Dasha and Hanson achieved in the IB programme," says David Boag, Associate Director of the Halton District School Board. "For many of our students, the IB program is a great complement to the high level of education they already receive in our Board. We wish Brian, Dasha and Hanson the best of good luck, as we are confident they will achieve much success in their future endeavours."

× Expand UnSplash White Oaks Secondary School

One factor that parents consider when purchasing a home is the quality of neighbouring high schools. Where do they rank? However, there is always more to consider than an institutional ranking and White Oaks Secondary School (WOSS) is a great example.

The Fraser Institute ranked White Oaks as the fourth best secondary school in Oakville. The top school being Oakville Trafalgar. White Oaks ranked as the 32nd best school in Ontario. The total number of secondary (catholic and public) schools ranked was 738.

Another factor to seriously consider are the accomplishments of the students. Let's take a look at the accomplishments of White Oaks Secondary School students during the past year:

1) Three White Oaks Students achieved perfect scores on the International Baccalaureate exam. There were only 13 students in the America's that achieved perfect scores.

2) At the Bay Area Science and Engineering Fair in Hamilton, White Oaks grade 9 student Sabrina Mogus won the Best-In-Fair award for her project ‘Need some TLC? Tigernut Liquid Cagulant: An undiscovered biocoagulant for water turbidity reduction.’ Also, her work received the award for Best High School Project. Sabrina was among four high school students selected to present at the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair in Phoenix, Arizona.

3) On June 7, 2019 Halton District School Board announced the achievements of:

Abby Robitaille Alex Wu Alice Chen Angie Lei Maza Algodi

Alice Chen achieved two outstanding results. In the French portion of the Canadian National debate championship at Montreal's Lower Canada College she captured top speaker . Alice also placed in the National Impromptu Concours Oratoire in Ottawa.

The National Finals in debate took place from May 24th to May 26th. Chen and fellow White Oaks Secondary School student Abby Robitaille placed first as the top French team in Canada. In the finals Chen placed first and Robitaille second.

In the Junior English portion of the debate competition, WOSS student Angie Lei won the John Robinson Trophy as the top Grade 9 speaker in Canada.

On June 1st, Grade 11 WOSS student Alex Wu placed second (Francophones) and Grade 11 WOSS student Hamza Algodi placed third (Core French) at the National Level Concours Oratoire (French public-speaking event).

White Oaks Secondary School may rank as the 32nd top Ontario school by the Fraser Institute, which incredible in it self. However, looking at the results of their students - parents would be hard pressed to find a better school.

Halton Regional Police say they have taken one person into custody following reports of a male with a gun in the area of White Oaks Secondary School in Oakville, Ont.

The suspect is in custody. Investigation ongoing. The Lockdown at White Oaks Secondary School and all other Hold & Secures have been lifted. No reports of injuries. There is no known, ongoing, related threat to public safety. Expect continued police presence in the area. — HRPS Oakville (@HRPSOak) May 31, 2022

Story continues below advertisement

Just after 2:30 p.m. on Tuesday, Halton Regional Police tweeted that White Oaks Secondary School was under lockdown, and that several other schools in the area were placed under hold and secure.

LOCKDOWN: White Oaks Secondary School is currently in lockdown for reports of a male with a firearm in the area. Other area schools will be going into Hold and Secure (details to follow). Heavy police presence, please avoid area. — HRPS Oakville (@HRPSOak) May 31, 2022

An hour later, police posted to Twitter saying one person had been taken into custody and the investigation was ongoing.

The lockdown and the hold and secures have been lifted, and police say there were no injuries or threat to public safety.
